title: Argumentum ad populum
summary: In argumentation theory, an argumentum ad populum (Latin for "appeal to the people"[1]) is a fallacious argument which is based on affirming that something is real because the majority thinks so.[2] Other names for the fallacy include common belief fallacy or appeal to (common) belief,[3][4] appeal to the majority,[5] appeal to the masses,[6] appeal to popularity,[7][8] argument from consensus,[9] authority of the many,[9][10] bandwagon fallacy,[8][11] consensus gentium (Latin for "agreement of the people"),[11] democratic fallacy,[12] mob appeal, and truth by association.[13]
